results.title: CES 2024: An earbud that functions like a brain implant
results.content: The best and brightest tech innovators are congregating in Las Vegas for CES 2024 (Consumer Electronics Show) to showcase the newest generation of technology. Naqi Logix — a neural interface developer — is one such company, seeking to make assisted living devices more accessible. Yahoo Finance's Akiko Fujita explores the functionality of Naqi Logix's earbuds which function as a non ...
results.raw_content:
CES 2024: An earbud that functions like a brain implant
The best and brightest tech innovators are congregating in Las Vegas for CES 2024 (Consumer Electronics Show) to showcase the newest generation of technology. Naqi Logix — a neural interface developer — is one such company, seeking to make assisted living devices more accessible.
Yahoo Finance's Akiko Fujita explores the functionality of Naqi Logix's earbuds which function as a non-invasive brain implant to engage with various home devices. She meets with Naqi Logix Founder David Segal and Director of Product Management Zavier Alexander to discuss the use cases of such technology.
Click here to view more of Yahoo Finance's coverage of CES 2024 this week, or you can watch this full episode of Yahoo Finance Live here.
Editor's note: This article was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.
Video Transcript
AKIKO FUJITA: "Yahoo Finance's" is on the ground here in Sin City, Las Vegas at CES 2024. It is one of the largest tech conferences in the world. We're here to give you the inside scoop on the technologies that will educate and enlighten and transform your portfolio.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
He's able to type by looking.
ZAVIER ALEXANDER: Exactly.
AKIKO FUJITA: Can we have him spell "Yahoo Finance?"
ZAVIER ALEXANDER: Sure.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
AKIKO FUJITA: We are here with Naqi Logix. It's a neural interface company that allows you to control digital devices like a laptop hands-free with this earpiece and facial gestures. He's not touching anything.
ZAVIER ALEXANDER: He's not touching anything. So this is totally hands-free right now. Totally, hands-free and voice-free. He's just looking at the text that he wants to type. And then it is being typed on screen.
AKIKO FUJITA: That is incredible. So this is all you need, the small earpiece.
ZAVIER ALEXANDER: Exactly. You can play a video game. You can fly a flight simulator. Dave can fly a 737 in the flight simulator on his computer.
- Look straight. Look up. Looking at the top panel.
- 1,000 sink rate. Pull up. Pull up. Pull up. Pull up.
DAVID SEGAL: I'm confident, if we can fly a 737 with nothing but an earbud, you can control anything and everything. And is that not the goal of implants?
AKIKO FUJITA: Well, then you don't need to implant the chip.
DAVID SEGAL: There you have it. That's why we're here at CES. I'm not against brain implants. That's very important to know because I think brain implants are very, very important for certain aspects of society. Those who are truly locked in, those who have severe neurological disorders, where technology like Naqi may not be a fit.
But for somebody who you want to consider a typical quadriplegic and healthier from that level up to and including healthy, able-bodied people like us--
AKIKO FUJITA: Yeah.
DAVID SEGAL: --this is the ability to almost telepathically hands-free, voice-free, and screen-free, control everything with nothing but a wearable.

CES 2024 Innovation Award Product
Naqi Neural Earbuds
By Naqi Logix Inc.
Honoree
Accessibility & Aging Tech
Naqi Neural Earbuds truly represent the next generation of Human-Machine Interfaces.  Our neural earbuds enable users to command, control, and navigate computers, digital devices, smart home IoT devices, robots, and wheelchairs without voice, touch, screens, or cameras. It's everyone's "earbud superpower” that can control almost everything in the digital world — appearing as if the user had telepathy.  Our neural earbuds will redefine how users interact with technology, creating an entirely new silent and invisible input methodology for the disabled, the elderly, gamers, e-sports professionals, and first responders.  Naqi Neural Earbuds are a safe, non-invasive alternative to brain implants.

results.title: Naqi Logix Neural Earbuds: Revolutionizing Accessibility and Winning ...
results.content: At Naqi Logix, we are honored to receive the Accessibility Award at CES 2024, recognizing our commitment to pushing the boundaries of what is possible in the realm of assistive technology. Our Neural Earbuds represent a leap forward in accessibility, empowering users to interact with the world around them in ways never thought possible.
results.raw_content:
Naqi Logix Neural Earbuds: Revolutionizing Accessibility and Winning Big at CES 2024
Introduction:
We are thrilled to announce that Naqi Logix Neural Earbuds have been recognized as one of the top 10 cutting-edge adaptive and accessible products at CES 2024! This prestigious award highlights the incredible impact our innovative Neural Earbuds are making in the world of assistive technology. Let's delve into why our product has secured its place among the winners and how it is shaping the future of accessibility.
The Future in Your Ears: Naqi Logix Neural Earbuds may look like your everyday Bluetooth headset, but make no mistake—they are far more advanced than meets the eye. These futuristic earbuds are equipped with embedded sensors that can detect brain waves and muscle impulses, translating them into powerful signals capable of controlling a vast array of devices.
Intuitive Control with Micro Gestures:
One of the standout features of our Neural Earbuds is the ability for users to intuitively command a host of devices through facial micro gestures. Imagine effortlessly controlling wheelchairs, drones, computers, and more—all without the need for touch or voice commands. It's a game-changer for individuals seeking a seamless and accessible way to interact with their environment.
Unleashing the Power of Neural Technology: The magic behind Naqi Logix Neural Earbuds lies in their capability to harness neural technology. By detecting and interpreting brain waves and muscle impulses, our earbuds empower users to interact with technology in ways that were once thought to be the stuff of science fiction. This groundbreaking innovation opens up new possibilities for individuals with diverse accessibility needs.
A Closer Look at CES 2024:
The CES 2024 Accessibility Awards celebrate products that are pushing the boundaries of innovation and making a positive impact on people's lives. Naqi Logix Neural Earbuds stood out among the competition, showcasing the true potential of assistive technology to enhance accessibility and inclusion.
What Sets Naqi Logix Apart:
Cutting-edge neural technology for intuitive device control.
Versatile compatibility with a wide range of devices.
No touch or voice required—simply use facial micro gestures.
An elegant design that seamlessly integrates into everyday life.
Conclusion:
At Naqi Logix, we are honored to receive the Accessibility Award at CES 2024, recognizing our commitment to pushing the boundaries of what is possible in the realm of assistive technology. Our Neural Earbuds represent a leap forward in accessibility, empowering users to interact with the world around them in ways never thought possible. As we continue to innovate and evolve, Naqi Logix remains dedicated to creating solutions that make a meaningful difference in the lives of individuals with unique accessibility needs. Join us on this journey towards a more inclusive and accessible future!

results.title: 'Neural' headphones are big at CES - here are 4 fascinating products ...
results.content: 1. Naqi Neural Earbuds Founder and chief innovation officer at Naqi Logix, Dave Segal, holds a Neural Earbud in his hand at CES Unveiled 2024. (Image credit: Future) Brain implants sound...
results.raw_content:
When you purchase through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Here’s how it works.
'Neural' headphones are big at CES – here are 4 fascinating products coming soon
The latest innovations in headphones tap into auditory nerves
Increasingly, competitors for the best headphones aren't just focused on delivering top-quality audio. Every year it seems that new strings are being added to their bow, and a big thing we're seeing in buds and headphones at CES 2024 are 'neural' technologies.
We also saw a couple more interesting earbuds pushing the boundaries of headphones tech, including TimeKettle's new multi-device X1 two-way translator earbuds and BREGGZ's in-ear computer wireless earbuds, which also have a translation app. With Samsung also looking to add real-time translation to its next Galaxy Buds, it's safe to say this is a tech we'll be hearing a lot more about.
But the idea of headphones being able to read minds is – in our opinion – even more outlandish, and therefore interesting. I've rounded up four neural headphones I spotted at CES 2024, all with very different designs.
1. Naqi Neural Earbuds
Brain implants sound like the stuff of science fiction but there are plenty of companies working on developing this tech for the consumer market. In this case, it's a company called Naqi Logix, which was co-founded by Dave Segal four years ago in Canada.
Segal tells me that the reason he invented wearable tech that could use electric signals from the brain to control various devices, from smart home electronics to even flight simulators, was inspired by a wish to help a friend who had become quadriplegic.
"We build the only neural earbuds on planet Earth that can serve as a safe, non-invasive alternative to brain implants. [They offer] the ability to have a full command of control over Windows and Mac computers, including typing, browsing, shopping and playing contemporary video games," Segal explains.
The idea behind the earbuds, which use gyroscopic, muscle and brainwave sensors, is that the computer interface tech inside them could be used in any of the best wireless earbuds to give them this added control. Given its ability to completely transform lives, it's no wonder why the Naqi Neural Earbuds was a CES Innovation Award honoree for accessibility and aging tech.
2. NeurGear ZenBud
Instead of sensing nerves and translating those signals to control a device like the Neural Earbuds above, NeurGear's ZenBud headset uses ultrasonic sound waves to relax you. The tech works by stimulating what's called the Vagus nerve, which is responsible for various bodily functions such as digestion, heart rate and breathing.
John Hacker, the founder and CEO of NearGear, explained to me that by stimulating a person's Vagus nerve, it triggers a rest response, which sends calming signals to the brain. This helps to "strengthen your stress resilience and your ability to relax. By using it just five minutes for a week, you can see marked increases in stress resilience and relaxation".
While the ZenBud is still in its early stages – NeurGear was only founded in 2021 – ultrasound tech like this could be rolled out to the best earbuds in the future. But if you want to try it out sooner then, as part of NeurGear's Kickstarter campaign, you can pre-order it now for $1 and receive a $100 discount off the purchase price, which is not yet known.
3. MyWaves Technologies Pebble
Pitched more as a headphone accessory, the myWaves Pebble device, which you can see in the picture above, attaches to your forehead to analyze your brain waves while sleeping to create custom music tracks that it claims will help you sleep.
"We have a science-backed technology that basically uses your delta waves, which are linked in your brain to sleep, to tell you all the activities of your sleep, from deep sleep to rapid eye movement (REM). By selecting a very specific part of your [delta waves while] sleep and turning it into music, we can produce music that triggers your brain to fall asleep quicker, longer and better," Jean Francois Destexhe, the CEO of myWaves Technologies, says.
Destexhe assures me that this device isn't meant to be worn every night, though. Instead, the idea is that you wear it for one night to get the recording. You then upload it to myWaves' platform, which next transforms your "brainwaves into lullabies to help you fall asleep faster".
You can currently sign up for early access to the tech, which was originally invented by Alain Destexhe and Luc Foubert, who are researchers of the Paris-Saclay Institute of Neuroscience (NeuroPSI), and receive a 40% discount off the price when it does become available.
4. Earable Neuroscience Frenz Brainband
Another company focusing on finding a solution to falling and staying asleep is Earable Neuroscience, which has been running since 2018 with the help of the University of Colorado and University of Oxford. Like myWaves, it also tracks your brain's signals to create a custom music track that promises to help you sleep but it instead has a developed a physical headset that you can wear above your ears.
The headset itself uses the same tech as the best bone conduction headphones to play the music, which Kimi Doan, chief growth officer at the company, says is much less intrusive and more comfortable than placing an earbud directly in the ear while trying to sleep. She tells me that "it tracks in real-time your brain activity signals and neuro feedbacks. Based on that, the AI will automatically personalize and select the digital therapeutics that are for your brain".
Earable Neuroscience currently has 18 patents in various stages of completion and is the winner of CES' Innovation Awards for 2024. It had also won the CES Awards for Wearables tech last year. If you want to be one of the first to try out its Frenz Brainband then you can pre-order it for $490, with it scheduled to be shipped by February 2024.
We’re covering all of the latest CES news from the show as it happens. Stick with us for the big stories on everything from 8K TVs and foldable displays to new phones, laptops, smart home gadgets, and the latest in AI.
And don’t forget to follow us on TikTok for the latest from the CES show floor!

With a background of more than eight years in tech and finance publishing, she's now leading our coverage to bring you a fresh perspective on everything to do with TV and audio. When she's not tinkering with the latest gadgets and gizmos in the ever-evolving world of home entertainment, you’ll find her watching movies, taking pictures and travelling.

results.title: Naqi Neural Earbuds may offer non-invasive option over brain implants
results.content: Company Naqi Logix showcased its high-tech neural earbuds at the CES 2024 (Consumer Electronics Show) in Las Vegas. The company states that neural earbuds mark a leap forward in the realm...
results.raw_content:
Neural earbuds may improve lives for those with mobility impairments
Naqi Logix
Get a daily digest of the latest news in tech, science, and technology, delivered right to your mailbox. Subscribe now.
By subscribing, you agree to our Terms of Use and Policies You may unsubscribe at any time.
Company Naqi Logix showcased its high-tech neural earbuds at the CES 2024 (Consumer Electronics Show) in Las Vegas.
The company states that neural earbuds mark a leap forward in the realm of Human-Machine Interfaces (HMIs).
These earbuds boast the capability to control a multitude of digital devices, creating an interface that appears almost “telepathic.”
Unlike brain implants, Naqi Neural Earbuds provide a safe, non-invasive alternative that is transforming how people interact with technology.
“Our neural earbuds enable users to command, control, and navigate computers, digital devices, smart home IoT devices, robots, and wheelchairs without voice, touch, screens, or cameras,” mentioned the company’s website.
As per the blog, these earphones detect small facial motions, like as jaw tightening or brow lifting, and transform them into actionable instructions, giving you more control over an unseen interface.
The possible applications for Naqi Earbuds are numerous, with a special emphasis on enhancing the lives of those with mobility disabilities. These earphones, which are currently under development, have the potential to provide users with unprecedented independence by allowing them to easily operate wheelchairs and smart-home gadgets.
In the company’s blog post, Dave Segal, the co-founder of Naqi Logix, shared the inspiration behind this groundbreaking technology. He explained that the invention of wearable tech capable of utilizing electric signals from the brain to control various devices was driven by a desire to assist a quadriplegic friend.
Segal describes this tech as "a safe, noninvasive, universal, invisible, and silent command and control system.
The potential for transforming lives has garnered the Naqi Neural Earbuds the CES Innovation Award honoree for accessibility and aging tech.
"This remarkable technology offers a bridge to enhanced mobility and control for those with disabilities, and it may extend its influence to entirely new domains, including the competitive landscape of professional gaming," mentioned the blog.
The Naqi Neural Earbuds demonstrate the capacity of technology to bring about good change, breaking obstacles for those with impairments.

Video Transcript
AKIKO FUJITA: "Yahoo Finance's" is on the ground here in Sin City, Las Vegas at CES 2024. It is one of the largest tech conferences in the world. We're here to give you the inside scoop on the technologies that will educate and enlighten and transform your portfolio.

He's able to type by looking.

ZAVIER ALEXANDER: He's not touching anything. So this is totally hands-free right now. Totally, hands-free and voice-free. He's just looking at the text that he wants to type. And then it is being typed on screen.
AKIKO FUJITA: That is incredible. So this is all you need, the small earpiece.
ZAVIER ALEXANDER: Exactly. You can play a video game. You can fly a flight simulator. Dave can fly a 737 in the flight simulator on his computer.

DAVID SEGAL: I'm confident, if we can fly a 737 with nothing but an earbud, you can control anything and everything. And is that not the goal of implants?
AKIKO FUJITA: Well, then you don't need to implant the chip.
DAVID SEGAL: There you have it. That's why we're here at CES. I'm not against brain implants. That's very important to know because I think brain implants are very, very important for certain aspects of society. Those who are truly locked in, those who have severe neurological disorders, where technology like Naqi may not be a fit.
But for somebody who you want to consider a typical quadriplegic and healthier from that level up to and including healthy, able-bodied people like us--

To be nominated for an Edison is one of the highest accolades any company can receive.
Naqi Logix, and our global team, are humbled and honored to receive this prestigious nomination.
Each and every Naqi team member, strategic partner, vendor, advisor, and investor has their fingerprints on this nomination.

You're the inspiration behind what made this nomination possible.

Naqi Logix was honored to be selected as a "FiReStarter" at this year's FiRe: Future in Review Conference, held this week at the Terranea Resort in Palos Verdes, CA.
We had the opportunity to demonstrate Naqi's technology and discuss our vision of how we can impact the smart earbud and AR/VR wearables markets while helping millions of people around the world who require assistive technology.
We wanted to thank Mark Anderson, Berit Anderson, Lee S Hall, and the entire FiRe: Future in Review staff for this incredible opportunity.
We also wanted to thank Kris KrÃ¼g for his wonderful company and amazing photos of our team.
Finally, we wanted to say that it was an honor to be included among the other FiReStarter Founders, all of which presented products and technologies that are sure to make the world a better place.

results.title: Wearable Tech Innovations at CES 2024: A Glimpse into the Future of ...
results.content: Naqi Logix's Neural Earbuds stole the spotlight at CES. These earbuds, equipped with "biosensors," detect the electrical impulses generated by facial expressions. Zavier Alexander, director of product management at Naqi Logix, explained how these earbuds can be programmed to control various connected devices, from keyboards and mice to ...
results.raw_content:
January 25, 2024
Technology products, solutions and news.
Wearable Tech Innovations at CES 2024: A Glimpse into the Future of Convenience, Safety, and Communication
Title: Wearable Tech Innovations at CES 2024: A Glimpse into the Future
Introduction:
The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas showcased an array of groundbreaking wearable tech innovations, bringing the once unimaginable into reality. From earbud remote controls to movie screen glasses, these advancements are set to revolutionize our daily lives. Let’s explore some of the highlights from CES 2024.
Earbud Remote Controls:
Naqi Logix’s Neural Earbuds stole the spotlight at CES. These earbuds, equipped with “biosensors,” detect the electrical impulses generated by facial expressions. Zavier Alexander, director of product management at Naqi Logix, explained how these earbuds can be programmed to control various connected devices, from keyboards and mice to flight simulators. Initially developed to help a paralyzed friend play video games, Naqi Logix is now seeking partnerships with headphone manufacturers to integrate this technology into their products.
Movie Screen Glasses:
XREAL’s augmented reality (AR) glasses offer users an immersive visual experience. These glasses project a movie theater-sized screen into thin air, providing a portable big-screen experience. Ralph Jodice, head of PR for XREAL, emphasized the versatility of these glasses, making them ideal for flights, car rides, or train journeys. With XREAL’s AR glasses, entertainment is no longer confined to a physical screen.
Enhanced Safety with Wearables:
Another notable innovation at CES was the .simstechnology device, designed to enhance personal safety. Worn on the back, this device alerts users when someone approaches. This technology has the potential to revolutionize personal safety, particularly in crowded environments or during outdoor activities.
Revolutionizing Communication:
Shift Robotics showcased their “moonwalkers,” a unique form of wearable transportation. Unlike traditional roller skates, these moonwalkers only move when the wearer walks. David Politis, marketing director at Shift Robotics, explained how this technology offers a new way to navigate urban environments without the need for traditional transportation methods.
Silent Mask for Enhanced Focus:
The Skyted silent mask offers a solution for those seeking uninterrupted focus. Designed to block out external noise and prevent the wearer’s voice from being heard, this mask allows for enhanced concentration and privacy. Stephane Hersen, founder of Skyted, highlighted the potential applications of this technology in various environments, including open offices and public spaces.
Conclusion:
CES 2024 showcased an impressive range of wearable tech innovations, demonstrating the potential to transform our daily lives. From controlling devices with facial gestures to experiencing a portable movie theater, these advancements offer convenience, safety, and enhanced communication. As wearable technology continues to evolve, we can expect even more exciting developments in the future.
#WearableTechInnovations #CES2024 #FutureTech #RevolutionizingCommunication #EnhancedSafety #ImmersiveExperience

results.title: Naqi has been nominated for a 2024 Edison Award
results.content: Naqi has been nominated for a 2024 Edison Award In the realm of technological innovation, Naqi stands as a pioneer, introducing a groundbreaking human-machine interface that has the potential to revolutionize the lives of individuals with disabilities.
results.raw_content:
Naqi has been nominated for a 2024 Edison Award
In the realm of technological innovation, Naqi stands as a pioneer, introducing a groundbreaking human-machine interface that has the potential to revolutionize the lives of individuals with disabilities. Through Naqi's ingenious design, a mere eye blink or a subtle head tilt becomes a powerful command to digital devices, offering newfound independence and agency to those who may have previously faced limitations. This remarkable interface extends its reach beyond personal convenience, allowing users to seamlessly control wheelchairs, manage smart homes, and command PCs—all without the need for touch, voice, or traditional screens.
Naqi's commitment to inclusivity is evident in its mission to empower not only those with disabilities but to make this transformative technology accessible to everyone. In the spirit of innovation and inclusiveness, Naqi honors the legacy of pioneers like Thomas Edison by providing an alternative to implants, ensuring that the benefits of this cutting-edge interface can be shared with the wider population. This dedication to democratizing accessibility aligns with Edison's ethos of making advancements that improve lives on a grand scale.
By showcasing Naqi's human-machine interface as a tool for productivity, this technology has the potential to redefine the way we interact with our digital world. The elimination of traditional input methods opens up a realm of possibilities, making productivity a universal experience that transcends physical abilities. Naqi's vision not only pays homage to the great minds of the past but also paves the way for a more inclusive and connected future, where the power to command technology lies at the blink of an eye or the tilt of a head.
